resources.string: CoronaMelder
en
Next
Example
Help stop the spread of the coronavirus
This app warns you if you\'ve been near someone with coronavirus. So you can prevent infecting people in your environment.
You get a notification after you’ve been exposed to a higher risk of infection
"The app notifies you when you've been near someone for at least 15 minutes who was later found to have coronavirus. This person must also use the app. "
The app uses Bluetooth, no location data
Using Bluetooth, the app sees whether you\'ve been near someone. The closer you\'ve been, the stronger the Bluetooth signal. The app doesn\'t know who you are or where you\'ve been.
Did someone cycle past you? Then you will not get a notification later
The Bluetooth signal was strong because you were near each other. But only for a very short time. This means your risk of infection is very low.
Did you sit near someone on the train? You could possibly get a notification later
The Bluetooth signal was strong enough and you were near each other for a longer period of time.
Turn on notifications about possible coronavirus exposure
Bluetooth data is saved on your phone for 14 days. You can always delete it yourself.
Your name will not be used or saved.
Your GPS location data will not be used or saved.
Turn on
How does the app work?

Are you sure you don\'t want to turn on these notifications?
Without permission the app won\'t be able to send you notifications after you\'ve been exposed to a higher risk of infection.

Let others know you\'re helping to stop the spread of the virus
The more people use CoronaMelder, the better it works. So share the app with as many people as you can. We can only stop the spread of the virus together.

Risk of infection
Getting a notification
You\'ve been near someone with coronavirus
What does it mean when you get a notification?

You were near someone %1$s (on %2$s) who was later found to have coronavirus. You were exposed to a higher risk of infection in this situation. If you are indeed infected, you can infect other people with coronavirus. Even if you don\'t feel sick right now.

The app sends you a notification if you\'ve spent 15 minutes near someone who was later found to have coronavirus. You\'ve been exposed to a higher risk of infection in this situation. If you are indeed infected, you can infect other people with coronavirus. Even if you don\'t feel sick right now.
What can you do now?
What can you do in this situation?

• No symptoms? Get a free coronavirus test
  • Do you have (mild) symptoms related to the coronavirus? Get tested for coronavirus and stay home until you get the results
  • Serious symptoms or part of a high-risk group? Call your doctor
Get tested for coronavirus
The GGD recommends you get tested for coronavirus. Even if you don\'t feel sick. Because you can still infect others and spread the virus without feeling sick.
"Get a free test. It doesn't take long to get tested and waiting times are mostly short. You get the results within 48 hours. In the meantime, stay home."
Call %1$s for free to request a coronavirus test.
Have your citizen service number (BSN) ready. You\'ll find it on your passport, identity card or nationality certificate.
Call for coronavirus test
Possible coronavirus (COVID-19) symptoms

• cold symptoms
  • nasal cold, runny nose, sneezing, sore throat
  • cough
  • elevated temperature
  • sudden loss of taste/smell
Request coronavirus test
Do you have symptoms related to the coronavirus? Get tested

Do you have (mild) symptoms related to the coronavirus? Get a free test. It doesn\'t take long to get tested and waiting times are usually short. You get the results within 48 hours. In the meantime, stay home. Serious symptoms or part of a high-risk group? Call your doctor.
Delete notification
Are you sure you want to delete this notification?
You won\'t be able to find the date in the app afterwards. So remember it well.

Frequently asked questions
Frequently asked question
Why is this app important?
Can the app see my location?
How can the app be anonymous?
When does the app send notifications?
How do I send a notification?
Can the Bluetooth signal pass through walls?
How much power does the app use?
How do I delete the Bluetooth data from my phone?
Why do my location services need to be turned on?
How exactly does the app work?

"This app helps the GGD with their research. So by using the app you help stop the spread of the coronavirus. If you've been tested and have coronavirus, you get a call from the GGD. During this call, the GGD asks you who you've been close to while contagious. The GGD also calls these people to warn them that they might have coronavirus."

However, you\'ve probably also been near people you don\'t know. In the train, cinema, or restaurant for example. This is where the app helps you. Because it allows you to warn all people who\'ve been near you. Including people you don\'t know. As long as they use the app, of course.

"The GGD contacts the people whose contact details you have. The app also warns people you've met, but whose name or contact details you don't know. So these people are quickly informed and able to take measures to prevent infecting others. The GGD's research continues. Because the people you've been close to more often might be at a higher risk. "

You can also receive warnings through the app. If this happens, it means you\'ve been near someone with coronavirus in last few days. In this case, you can do your part to prevent spreading the virus to others. Do so by paying extra attention to (mild) symptoms related to coronavirus. And by getting tested should you experience any of these symptoms.

No. Using Bluetooth, the app only sees whether you\'re near other people who also have the app. Bluetooth isn\'t linked to your location, so the app can\'t see where you are. Bluetooth only wirelessly connects 2 devices that are near each other. Like your phone and a speaker, or a pair of headphones.

The app exchanges codes with other phones. These codes don\'t include any of your personal or location data. They\'re completely random. The code exchange happens when you\'re near a person who also has the app.

Was this person later found to have coronavirus? They can use the app to add their codes to a list of infected people. Adding codes is only possible after the infected person gives a GGD key to the GGD. Then, you and others who have these codes on their phones get a notification. This notification only says when you\'ve been close to an infected person. Not who this person is and where you\'ve encountered them.

You get a notification after you\'ve been exposed to a higher risk of infection. This happens if you\'ve spent 15 minutes near someone who was later found to have coronavirus. That person must be using the app too. Whether or not you get a notification depends on the strength of the Bluetooth signal and the duration of your encounter. Did someone cycle past you on the street? Then you won\'t get a notification later. Yes, the Bluetooth signal was strong because you were near each other. But you were near each other for such a short time that your risk of infection is very low. Were you near someone on the train or in the office? Then you could get a notification later. The Bluetooth signal was strong and you were near each other for a longer period of time.

You can only send a notification to others if you have coronavirus. In this case, you\'ll get a call from the GGD. During this call a GGD employee checks your GGD key. You can find this key in the app. Using this method we make sure only people who are really infected can send notifications to others.
"After your GGD key is checked, the people who were near you when you were contagious could get an anonymous notification. Only if these people also use the app."

Yes, but the signal would be very weak. Bluetooth works best when your phone is in the same room as another person\'s phone. So the chance of you getting your neighbours\' Bluetooth signal is very low. That also means you probably won\'t get a notification if your neighbour has corona and you haven\'t been in the same room.
The app uses Bluetooth Low Energy — a special kind of Bluetooth that only uses a tiny bit of power. How fast this drains your battery depends on your phone.

"You can delete the Bluetooth files saved by the app yourself. Here's how that's done. Go to the settings menu on your phone -> Google -> COVID-19 Exposure Notification. Tap on Delete random IDs -> Delete. Don't want the app to save new Bluetooth data? Delete the app. "
Open Settings

Some apps use Bluetooth to determine your location. That\'s why it\'s part of your location settings. CoronaMelder needs Bluetooth to work, but it only uses Bluetooth to see if you\'ve been near someone else who uses the app. The app never knows your location.
Technical explanation
1. The app makes a unique code for each phone
This code doesn\'t include any information about you or your phone. The code is completely anonymous and changes every 15 minutes.
2. Phones only exchange codes when they\'re near each other

Does the person you run into also have the app? Then your phones use Bluetooth Low Energy to exchange codes. This way, the app knows which phones were near you. The app doesn\'t know who the phones belong to. And it doesn\'t know where you were.
3. If someone has coronavirus they can put their codes on a list

This list only contains the codes of infected peoples. All codes older than 14 days are automatically deleted. An infected person can add their codes to this list. To do so, they need to give a so-called GGD key to the GGD. This guarantees the added codes actually belong to someone with coronavirus.
4. Each phone checks whether it has seen the codes on the list before

A few times a day, the app checks the list which has codes of infected people. And it compares these codes with the codes saved on your phone. This is how the app sees whether you\'ve been exposed to a higher risk of infection.
5. You get a notification if an infected person\'s codes are on your phone

This notification tells you when you\'ve been near an infected person. Not who this person is, or where you\'ve run into them. The app lets you know what you can do next. Your own codes aren\'t on the list of infected codes. They\'re saved on your phone for 14 days.
Check the source code
Go to Github

The Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sports has decided that the app is no longer necessary. From now on, you won\'t get a notification after you\'ve been near someone with coronavirus.

You\'ve turned off notifications. So you won\'t get a notification when you\'ve been near someone with coronavirus.

"Yellow circle with exclamation mark as warning "
Red circle with alarm bell that shows you need to take action immediately
Warning
Important
What does test and research version mean?
Test and research version %1$s (%2$s)
Read more

Keep following the rules:
  • Regularly wash your hands
  • Cough/sneeze into your elbow
  • Keep a 1.5 metre distance from people outside of your household
Permission to use data
To use CoronaMelder, you have to accept the privacy statement. Important to know:
Your app sends out encrypted Bluetooth data.
Other users who\'ve been in contact with you save this data for a maximum of 14 days.
If you\'ve been tested and have coronavirus, you can report it in the app to warn other users.
You can delete the data off your phone whenever you want.
I\'ve read and accepted the privacy statement
Get a free test. It doesn\'t take long to get tested and waiting times are mostly short. You get the results within 48 hours. In the meantime stay home.
How does this work?
